item.title: Mac minis are the new ASIC miners — 62 replies — 37.6/hr
item.content:encoded:
Mac minis are the new ASIC miners

Open thread • Replies: 62 • Updated: 2026-02-25 16:00 UTC

OP

Mac minis are like the ASIC miners except they do actual work instead of mining bitcoin for no reason.

Early replies (first 3)

61893585
>>61893434
What are people even doing with their 50 mac mini AI agents?

61893611
>>61893585
Its like a team of 50 indians

61893612
>>61893611
Just imagine the sound of 50 echoing good morning sirs

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61895888
>>61895868
no one is running the actual model locally, this is for running the agent and all its tools, most people are running API calls off Openrouter

61895922
>>61895888
These ARE running local models, that's the entire point of using MacMinis and unified RAM. Whether the Minis will survive the experience, is another issue entirely.

61896004
>>61895757
Interesting.
Mine kept saying im trans. Kek!
> sadface.jpg

61896011
>>61894156
>>give the mac mini all of my personal info, financial data, passwords, internet browsing history etc.
It's a personal computer. It already has all of those things.

61896031
>>61895820
Yes that’s pretty much it. Although it did help me diagnose leaky gut issues and initially helped with some supplements, but then it started telling me to basically OD on magnesium and electrolytes.

61896090
>>61894238
Rent it to people that are scared of running it locally or too stupid to figure it out.
Stuff like this https://seafloor.bot/

61896126
Basically in the future everyone will have their own personal agentic AI, and these people are hosting them while its still hard to get it set up.
This isnt a sustainable business model tho, because its only a matter of time before soke big company like google starts doing it with infinitely more success because they actually have all the data from everyone, so the AI assistant will come out of factory already knowing you better than you know yourself.
But it will be profitable probably for a 1 or 2. I dont see this stuff getting released by a big company before its tested enough to ensure most of the nightmarish stories being reported about openclaw have a close to 0% chance of happening.

61896174
>>61893434
>they do actual work
how much money has your agent made?

61896193
>>61895922
No they aren't. They're just a bunch of iToddlers who can't into Raspberry Pi or Linux.

61896922
>>61896126
>knowing you better than you know yourself
it's actually pretty hard to personalize large language models, so dont expect the same behaviour as you have from your tiktok or youtube algorithm

61896954
this is pure retardium. the minis are not running shit. they can't run any models, and anyways open models are not worth running, they're dumb as rocks
openclaw uses api to run, claude because it's the only one that can do shit. the fattest claude (the only able one) can burn hundreds of $$$ per day. and you don't need a mac mini for it. you can just run it on the cloud or in a virtual machine. it's really lean on resources - you just need to pay a lot of money for the api
dumb. all of it is just dumb

61896995
>>61895757
Must be a canadian llm, MAID GPT.

61897015
>>61896193
It's the same software. If you can't into linux then you definitely can't into macos. Both start up into a first class GUI and both require you to drop to the command line to install LLM shit because that's how the software works. Ollama front ends not withstanding.
Hell, raspi clusters are easy mode because it far easier to find a prebaked recipe you can copy/paste to get it all running whereas mac users have to deal with retards hardcoding paths and cuda bullshit into their workflows.
That said there is some retardation going on with the mac buying. Macs are the sane choice because they are the absolute cheapest way to get more than 64GB with GPU access to that pool. Your 128GB of DDR5 and a xeon doesn't compare. Buying a joblot of 16GB mac minis is defeating the purpose though.

61897157
>>61895163
correct

>>61895732
wrong. AMD GPUs out on price to performance ratios for AI as long as you have enough IQ to configure rocm kernel

61897160
>>61897157
*AMD GPUs win out

61898771
>>61897157
I'll believe it when I see it. A PC with enough VRAM on the GPU to beat mac, I don't think it works. Plus that pc has to do offloading.

61899637
>>61893699
Computer engineer here:
The thing that makes the M chips a game-changer is that they use AI to accelerate AI workloads. The result? AI squared. This has been the holy grail of the mac mini’s eye-watering efficiency. I guarantee you that in five years, every AI PC on the market will use AI to accelerate its AI accelerator for AI. AI cubed, if you will.

61899711
>>61893434
who else running stealth asics hidden in the attic at their office? place is full of dumb cunts that wouldn't even find it if i told them it was there

61899788
>>61898771
>>61895922
Nonsense. Mac unified memory is slow because it has low memory bandwidth which is very important for fast inference.
Offloading is not a needed when you have real GPUs with 96-256GB memory capacity.

Minis are good for single core tasks (python/js) and ARM is power efficient so I guess it's suited for API agents. Local LLMs are worse for most tasks anyway.

61899789
>>61896192
This has been the case for both crypto and AI, but at least the latter is useful for most people.

61899866
>>61895191
i use a local LLM to write passable warhammer fantasy stories for me

61899869
>>61899637
e = mc^2 + AI

61900078
>>61899788
>Local LLMs are worse for most tasks anyway.
What are they good for?

61900675
>>61895163
Its almost entirely about ram costs. A single mac studio with 512 gb of unified memory can run a monster of a local AI set up. Hundreds of billions of parameters. To build a PC with 512 gb of vram is basically impossible, so you are stuck using less efficient 512gb ddr5 + CPU set ups for twice the price and half the performance. Mac studio/mini is the ideal locally hosted AI machine by a wide margin, both price and performance wise.

61900701
>>61896193
This is the opinion of poor brainlets. MacOS is unix based. The GUI is set up for normies and retards, so they cant fuck anything up, but the terminal is pretty much identical to a linux terminal in both function and syntax. Local AI set ups like openclaw and ollama require use of the terminal to set up currently. That means anyone who has set up a locally hosted agentic AI on a mac likely knows the linux terminal better than you do.

61900832
>>61897157
People here are genius-level retards.
The technical bottleneck for real-world autonomous agent usage isn't raw speed (tokens per second). The actual bottleneck is realistically supportable model size and ability to support many simultaneous agents with tooling coordinating together. If you're running automation 24/7, you don't care if an individual task takes a few seconds, minutes, or sometimes even hours longer: you care that the model you're running is smart enough to solve your tasks successfully in a reasonable amount of time. This means fitting into some kind of RAM, even if it's not the fastest RAM available.
Now of course, if you're an autist and want to add a few server racks in your house, you could theoretically build a larger and far faster system with rocm. But the setup for that isn't trivial, you either need to find a way to stuff a pile of expensive power-hungry GPUs into one machine to get as much RAM as a Mac Mini/Studio has or build some kind of cluster (which is itself a big headache). Either you're stuck doing it over Ethernet (a bottleneck which reduces the speed advantage your system has, versus it being nearly trivial to use the far faster Thunderbolt to build a small Mac cluster if you want to) or you need to spend literally tens of thousands of dollars on some kind of Infiniband setup. The unified system memory approach of the Macs (even if it's slower than VRAM) means that a local setup you have could be much smarter as it's realistic to build a significantly larger memory setup. It's easier to have in your house (try justifying to your wife that you want a few server racks setup somewhere) versus a Mac Studio or two that you can hide under the corner of your desk.
I haven't even gotten to the part about literally paying thousands of dollars more per year in electricity costs for such a setup over the Mac equivalent.

61900903
>>61900701
>MacOS is unix based.
MacOS is literally Unix and has a much better claim on that title than Linux, which is rightfully often called "unix-like".

61900925
>>61900903
Born Again SHell (Bash) is the standardization mechanism between the two.

61900928
>>61895163
>with current RAM prices and how scarce GPU's with decent VRAM
The bubble is already popping. I just saw a headline yesterday that one of the big AI scams has cut back its expected datacenter buildout shekels from $1.4 trillion to $600 billion.

Expect to see a lot more of that. They can't even get the electrical power, and no, "small modular nuclear reactors" aren't going to magically appear and get approved in the next six months (or even five years) to solve that.

item.title: Redpil me on the Florida and Broader US Housing Market — 16 replies — 15.3/hr
item.content:encoded:
Redpil me on the Florida and Broader US Housing Market

Open thread • Replies: 16 • Updated: 2026-02-25 16:36 UTC

OP

> I'm an anon nearing 40, saved appropriately
> Finally at a stage to buy an investment property, ideally a condo / box in the sky
> Looking into Jupiter, Florida
> "Whoa, this condo was built after 2005, and the ask is $400K for 1200 square feet in a prime shopping area"
> Insurance comes out to $4-500 per month
> HOAs from $300-800 per month in this market
> Property taxes are eliminated?
> Cape Coral is literally a firesale
> Bake in a 8% vacancy rate
> Plus some maintenance
> I would have to charge $5,000 a month to break even? WTF

What is going on anons? What are you seeing out there? Would it be more prudent to invest in the Northeast (VT, NH, ME?) Is anyone doing okayish on investment income on a single family? What has been your experience?

Early replies (first 3)

61891143
>>61891078
As a shareholder I look down on landlord parasites. Invest in making people's lives better by providing a product/service, not holding people's living space hostage

61891189
>>61891078
You don't understand math or taxes which is why you're 40 and homeless

61891197
>>61891078
why?

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61892463
>>61891143
The more independent landlords there are, the more it decentralizes power from larger corporations like Blackrock

>>61891189
I'm doing very well

>>61891197
I'm already invested into stocks, and precious metals. Now would be the time to invest in real estate

61895578
>>61891078
Economics aside Cape Coral is a bit of a meme.
The Cape is what would happen if you had an idea guy design a city and that idea is to just chop up everything with canals.
(Not a great idea, you’re still going to be driving everywhere 90% of the time and the canals just make the road layout 3x worse than a normal city)

61897144
>>61891078
> ideally a condo / box in the sky
> Insurance comes out to $4-500 per month
> HOAs from $300-800 per month in this market
> I would have to charge $5,000 a month to break even? WTF

Invest in multiplexes, don't limit yourself to a single location, and NEVER be negative cashflow. If it doesn't cashflow, you don't buy it. This should be obvious.

61897152
>>61891078
Do you guys think the next big hurricane will be the straw that breaks the camel's back? There hasn't been a real bad one to his a high population center in Florida in awhile. The latest ones were mild, even the one the wrecked north Carolina

61897153
This whole state sinks with 5 meters of sea level rise most roads go immediately out of comission. Biggest meme state ever

61897155
>$5k a month
sounds about right.

61897915
>>61891078
I live in florida and how is the insurance 4500 a month for a condo? how old is the building?

ref im at around 7k a year on ins and hoa for house is 200 a month

>>61897153
>if the oceans raise 15ft its over
well no shit anon

61897987
>>61897155
Comparable rents are like $1,800-3,200 maximum. And if you go into the MLS, landlord have been chopping their asking rent prices constantly, and still no bites.
>>61897155
I said $4-500 as in $400-500 per month. You said get charged $7,000 a year on insurance, so that's $583 per month, which is about what I would expect.
>>61897153
At this point, it seems like the "VSTAX and chill" meme is where it's at.

61898594
>>61891078
>Would it be more prudent to invest in the Northeast
Yes, Florida is designed to extract as much wealth from boomers as possible. There are ways to take advantage of this but buying boomer bags is not one of them.

61898758
>>61891078
Almost nothing is cashflowing. Maybe some Airbnbs but few and far between. Rents are too low for the cost of loans right now. Either interest or property values go down, or rents go up, but I don't seerent going up.

>>61898594
This. You're supposed to take money from boomers, not give it to them.

61899686
>>>>61891078
>>61891078
As a florida anon: FL real estate is such a scam nowadays. Maybe it always has been.

For your example, it's because the HOA reserves need to be maximized and not gutted, alongside property insurance within the state has now 300-500x+ since Helene and the past decade of storms. Combined with global warming, warmer waters in atlantic/gulf=stronger hurricanes, and ocean level increasing + most of FL property is under sea level so flood zone. It's practically had me leave the state.

If you so desire the FL lifestyle, an old block house with 5000sq ft+ land is the way to go, not in a flood zone makes it every affordable even if it isn't a coastal/near beach, it's just not worth the price point. I've relocated to Seattle and then Tokyo and my rent and mortgage are 1:1 in Seattle, if not cheaper there, where in JPland it's half, literally, 50% USA price. I was fortunate to profit during 08-16, but nowadays, cheaper to rent and leave the bag holders in FL.

Then the tenants suck in FL, while strong landlord laws, the tenants are shit, the handyman are worse and to repair and such will be a hassle. ergo it's fun to fuck with landlords, you can literally negotiate that you'd leave after a month with no other penalty, just make sure to close those utilities anon. t. floridian4lyfe.

>>61897987
VSTAX is where it’s at, if you're a pussy, vanguard or swvvx is okay too.

61900797
Use ai to comb census data. Florida has 900 zip codes but 20 are 100% white. That's where you buy property. You can get up to 4 units on an FHA loan. Bonus points if it's a little cafe or bakery downtown with apartments above it.

61901094
>>61891078
You’re better off parking your cash in an REIT and yielding 7% than doing this shit. Insurance is extremely high, HOA fees are enormous, and boomers are greedy. Market has to adjust for that bullshit before it becomes profitable again

item.content:encoded:
BBBY-WT insider here

Open thread • Replies: 8 • Updated: 2026-02-25 17:06 UTC

OP

right before your stocks and crypto were crashing, i told you to buy bbby-wt. it was $0.64 at the time, and now it is $0.89. buy before it is too late. the warrant supply is decreasing every trading day. yes, you can expect significant returns on this over the next two months.

Early replies (first 3)

61900433
is /biz/ ready?

61900445
>>61899886
085

61900468
>>61899886
Thank you for the advice. I'm buying up as many as I can. I heard that the CUSIP on BBBY warrants actually belong to BBBYQ, which proves a reverse merger has ALREADY taken place. What a time to be alive!

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61900478
>>61900433
What like a 10x?

61900943
>>61900468
The warrants are for BBBY, not BBBYQ. You can't issue warrants for a stock that no longer exists.

61901058
>>61900943
Precisely. BBBY issued warrants using BBBYQ's CUSIP. This means that BBBYQ reverse merged with BBBY. BBBYQ issued the warrants because they are the entity in control of BBBY now.

61901108
>>61901058
Nope, they are not related and no merger or reverse merger has taken place. This was confirmed by the issuer of the warrants, Marcus Lemonis.

61901236
>>61901108
That's not true. The issuing entity was BBBYQ because the Identifier belongs to BBBYQ.

Have you tried not living in Alaska?
>pawn broker says they only pay 90% of spot price, including a 12% processing fee
So they pay 2% over spot...Nice
>IRS also collects 28% in taxes
Common misconception that precious metals are taxed at 28%. The reality is that you owe tax according to your income bracket which means that if you make around $60k per year you only owe 12% on precious metals capital gains. If you make $600k+ per year then yes you will owe 28%.
>halfway there, spending another 20 bucks on gas, my back left tire blew out.
What does this have to do with silver?
>didnt have a spare
You make $600k per year and you can't afford a spare tire???
